weakness in the step they had taken. The Russian Government first accedes to a most important political step and then at the last moment withdraws ite sanction. But instead of putting an absolute veto on the conference it allows the representatives of the Zemstvos to meet in private. The consequences were obvious Radical resolutions are adopted, a Constitution is demanded, together with liberty of conscience, liberty of the Press, liberty of speech, and liberty of education, besides an elective legislative assembly. This private conference was only held on Saturday, but by Monday the facts are known to the world and the ball has been set rolling which, under the leadership of a Slavonic Mirabeau or Lafs- yette, may lead to the ruin of militant auto- eracy throughout the Russian Empire:

At the same time, serious observers of the conditions of modern Russis, even among those who sympathise with the aspirations of the Russian people for a form of government which will give some legitimate scope for their ener gies, entertain grave doubts as to the capacity of the Russians for self-government. The mem- bers of the bureaucracy, indeed, base their claim to govern Russia, when they condescend to argue the matter at all; on the ground that acceptance of office the new Minister of the In- no other government is possible. Soon after his

terior made a mendorable declaration." Abroad," said Prince Sviatopolk Mirski, "people speak of a new Constitution for Russia: such a thing is, impossible under present conditions.". It is not only abroad that people speak of a new Constitu tion; it is in Russia itself that the demand is being did not stop short at a repetition of the common made. But Prince Sviatopolk-Mirski's declaration official formula. "But," he continued, "there is such a thing as local self-government, as is exemplified in the Zemstvos. I believe," he added, "in Zematvos." That is a declaration of immense importance coming from such a quarter how important is demonstrated, with singular appositeness in an article on "Self-government in Russia" in the new number of the Empirs Review. For reasons which may readily be sur mised, the writer of the article desires to pre- serve his anonymity; but internal evidence renders almost superfluous the editorial as surance that the writer is entitled to be listened to with respect when he seeks to supplement Prince Sviatopolk-Mirski's state- mont by giving a sketch of the Zemstvo institution in Russia. The evidence which THEOFPTIAN GASETTE IS PRINTED ON PAPER is adduced of the existence of the seeds of a representative system of government throughout the greater part of European

HEDJAZ RAILWAY. Marshal Kiazim Pasha, director of the works of the Hedjar Railway, has telegraphically communicated to the High Commission for that line a summary of the contents of the chief engineer's report on the work done during this report, the work is making good progress the past month, beyond Maan. According to both as regards the earthworks and the build- ing of bridges and tunnels. The boring of tunnels Nos. 1 and 5 is very shortly to be taken in hand. Tunnel No. 2 has been bored, No. 3 has been commenced, No. 4 is practically finished, and No. 6 is completely finished.

Helouan, Monday-The dust of the long summer months has been effectively laid to-day by a sharp shower of 10 minutes, when 2 mil limetres of rain fall. The atmosphere has also been cleared of dust, and the desert air is now as crisp and bracing as one could wish for. A company of Royal Engineers are encamped behind the Tewfik Palace Hotel for the annual field exercises.

A un moment donné la question des protéts a captivé l'attention de la presse égyptienne, des juristes et des chambres de commerce. Lears avis étaient par- sagés, mais un point. sur lequel tous étaient d'accord, c'était celui de réduire le coût du protés, qui; comme on le sait, s'élève à 58 r.T. sans compter les frais Le marché est légèrement oppressé. Le mou- de déplacement de l'huissier. En effet, Ivement s'est concentré sur les Cotton Mills qui protêt, pour être logique, devrait être atteignent 8/3 acheteurs et la Salt & Soda qui fléchit à 39/3. établi proportionnellement en montant d l'effet et non sur une base unique de 68 P.T., que la traite soit d'ailleurs d'une ou de cent livres égyptiennes.
Mais si le prix du protés est excessif pour les effets de moindre valear, nous ne eroyons pas qu'il en soit ainsi pour les autres et voici pourquoi:

Sir, Whilst desiring to endorse the tribute The Port steam tug Hawke (Captain Taglis paid by "Unicorn" to the designer of the Tues. 23 ferro, late of the Khedivial Mail Line) leaves bridge, it occurs to me that had he been a to-day for Suez and will, on arrival there, go little more expert in clairvoyance and heraldry into dry dock for painting and general repairs. he would have symbolised British supremacy Another big shower of rain came down upon the Nile by the Lion Rampant ! yesterday but has done no damage worth I am, etc., Laos KING-AT-ARMS

2,777,209 & 4 The Suskin International Club, which was opened some time ago, is doing well, and its 922,149 19 7 members have greatly increased. Its supporters Are the leading merchants of Suskin, and they 46,430 16 10 thoroughly enjoy the club during the dull winter evenings. Some sports and boating £6,953,624 12 7 races are being got up. A swimming bath is attached to the club.

Graham's Point in very lively now. It has become quite a little colony with the cottages for workmen built by the Railways. A coffee shop and canteen have sprung up, and, in 4,092,350 12-5 less than a year a desert has been trasformed into a busy European colony. The Arab workmen also enjoy the bright English cottages, 25,000 00 which they have never seen before.

The construction of some squash. racket courts at the Alexandria Cricket Club's grounds will be taken in hand within the next few weeks.
Before the end of the year the club expect to lay down a third asphalt tennis court in place of the existing sand court.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Dear Sir, I have just read with some sur. Fri. 9 prise that I climbed on to the mast of the Sat 10 small steamer which followed the Greek squa- Wed, 21 dron yesterday afternoon out of Alexandria harbour.
I thank you for this compliment, which, were it exact, would speak highly of my agility, and I cannot help regretting that such was not the case.
I would, I confess it, be quite incapable of performing such a feat. I remain, dear Sir, Yours faithfully, Alexandria, November 21.-
